newsitem.title: UK: Robust July demand, Iraq delays lift N. Sea crudes.
newsitem.headline: Robust July demand, Iraq delays lift N. Sea crudes.

text.p: North Sea crudes were firmer across the board on Thursday, boosted by strong early July demand and uncertainty over when Iraq would resume crude exports under the U.N. oil-for-food deal, traders said.
Forties and Norwegian Ekofisk were in particularly strong demand with at least three cargoes of each grade trading at firmer differentials than the last reported deals, they said.
French refiners featured as the main buyers, paying Dated Brent +20 cents for Ekofisk and Dated +25 cents for Forties.
Dated Brent was also firmer but talk of a trade as strong as Aug Brent -30 cents could not be confirmed.
"There is precious little left in any grade for the first 10 days so if you want barrels you're going to have to pay solid numbers," said a trader.
August Brent was unchanged at $17.77 a barrel by 1721 GMT, tracking IPE futures, but 15-day intermonth paper spreads firmed throughout the day.
July/August traded at least three times at -16 cents early in the session, a cent or two firmer than late U.S. dealing on Wednesday, and by late afternoon was talked around -15 cents.
Brent CFDs for June 23-27 jumped six cents from trade at August -31 cents amid a scarcity of the benchmark grade.

Five of the first six cargoes from the July loading programme are in the hands of a European major oil company. The sixth, a July 4-6 loader which turned wet on Thursday, was kept by Wall Street trader Phibro.

Traders said Iraq's refusal to resume exports until the remaining $800 million of revenue from the first 180 days of the U.N. deal has been spent on humanitarian supplies was providing a supportive backdrop.
"The longer the Iraqi delay the tighter everything starts to look," said a North Sea trader.
